title: Erdős #401: Factorial Divisibility with Prime Products

problemStatement.formal: \exists f(r) \to \infty: \exists^\infty n, \exists a_1, a_2: a_1! a_2! | n! \cdot 2^n 3^n \cdots p_r^n \land a_1 + a_2 > n + f(r) \log n
problemStatement.plain: Does there exist f(r) → ∞ such that for infinitely many n, we can find a₁, a₂ with a₁!a₂! | n!·2ⁿ3ⁿ...pᵣⁿ and a₁ + a₂ > n + f(r)·log n?
whyMatters: Primorial factors provide extra 'room' in divisibility

proven: Erdős-Graham: Without extra factors, a₁+a₂ ≤ n + O(log n)
Sothanaphan: 'For all large n' version is FALSE

currentState.focus: PROVED. Main theorem erdos_401_proved established via Barreto-Leeham construction.

knowledge.progressSummary: COMPLETE (PROVED): Erdos401Problem.lean (177 lines, 6 axioms, 0 sorries). Main theorem erdos_401_proved ESTABLISHED. Barreto-Leeham construction axiomatized. Connection to Problem #729 formalized. Sothanaphan counterexample for strong version.
insights: Key: primorial factors provide extra divisibility room
Baseline: Erdős-Graham shows O(log n) without extra factors
Strong version (∀ large n) is FALSE (Sothanaphan)

papers: Erdős-Graham (1980): Old and New Problems, p.78
